gameIntro.title: What is Meitra?
gameIntro.subtitle: A Strategic Japanese Partnership Card Game
gameIntro.description: Meitra (明専トランプ, Meisen Trump) is a sophisticated 4-player partnership trick-taking card game originating from Japan. If you're familiar with Bridge, you'll recognize many similarities—but Meitra introduces unique mechanics like the Jack system, Broken hands, and Chombo violations that create a distinct strategic experience.
gameIntro.feature1: Partnership Play: 4 players in 2 teams, partners sit opposite
gameIntro.feature2: Strategic Bidding: 'Blow' phase similar to Bridge's auction
gameIntro.feature3: Unique Mechanics: Special Jack hierarchy, JOKER power, and Tra trump
gameIntro.feature4: Risk & Reward: Declare your tricks wisely—success brings points, failure brings penalties
gameIntro.feature5: Violation System: 'Chombo' penalties add strategic depth
gameIntro.setupDesc: Meitra uses a modified 53-card deck: cards 5 through Ace in all four suits (♠♥♦♣), plus one JOKER. Cards 2, 3, and 4 are excluded from play but used separately as score markers.
gameIntro.phase1Desc: Each player receives 10 cards. One card remains face-down as the 'hidden card.'
gameIntro.phase2Desc: Players take turns declaring how many 'pairs' (tricks) they can win out of 10, and which suit will be trump. Like Bridge's auction, higher bids override lower ones. Minimum bid: 6 pairs.
gameIntro.phase3Desc: The highest bidder (dealer) leads. Players compete to win tricks following standard trick-taking rules with trump and base suit bonuses. Play continues for 10 tricks.
gameIntro.phase4Desc: Points are calculated based on whether the declaring team achieved their bid. First team to 10 points wins!
gameIntro.mechanic1Desc: Unlike Bridge's complex suit ranking, Meitra uses five trump types with clear hierarchy: Tra (special no-trump) > Hearts > Diamonds > Clubs > Spades. Players bid both the number of tricks AND the trump suit, creating layered strategic decisions.
gameIntro.mechanic2Desc: When a trump suit is declared (except Tra), two Jacks become super-powered: the 'Main J' (Jack of trump suit) and 'Sub J' (Jack of same color as trump). These become the 2nd and 3rd strongest cards after JOKER, adding tactical depth to hand evaluation.
gameIntro.mechanic3Desc: Weak hands (no face cards, or only one Queen) enter a 'Broken' state with special rules. If you hold all four Jacks, you MUST declare Broken—this is called 'Required Broken' and failing to do so is a violation.
gameIntro.mechanic4Desc: Before play begins, each player secretly selects their 'Negri' (weakest/unwanted card). This seemingly simple decision has strategic implications and forgetting to select is a Chombo violation!
gameIntro.mechanic5Desc: Meitra includes a violation system where opponents can call out rule-breaking: Negri Forget, Four-Jack violations, Last Tanzen (ending with JOKER), and wrong Broken declarations. Only the opposing team can report violations, adding a competitive edge.
gameIntro.bridgeComparisonDesc: Think of Meitra as Bridge's Japanese cousin with a twist. The Blow phase is your auction, pairs are tricks, and the dealer is the declarer. However, Meitra adds unique flavor with its Jack system, simplified trump hierarchy, special violation rules, and the mysterious Tra trump that changes the game dynamics entirely.
gameIntro.scoringFormula: Formula: If you meet or exceed your bid (Y ≥ X): 0.5×(Y-X) + X - 5 points | If you fail (Y < X): Y - X points (negative)
gameIntro.scoringNote: Notice: Exceeding your bid gives modest bonuses (0.5× multiplier), but failing gives harsh penalties (full difference). This encourages realistic bidding!
gameIntro.culturalNoteDesc: Meitra originated in Japanese student circles, where creative trump-based games developed unique local rules. The name '明専トランプ' (Meisen Trump) references its origins. Terms like 'Blow' (declaration), 'Negri' (unwanted), and 'Chombo' (violation) are Japanese gaming terminology that add character to the game.
gameIntro.readyToPlayDesc: Now that you understand the basics, dive into the detailed rules to master the Jack system, learn optimal bidding strategies, and discover the nuances that make Meitra a deeply strategic partnership game. Good luck, and may your Blows be bold!

overview.title: Game Overview
overview.bridgeNote: Note for Bridge Players: Meitra is similar to Bridge - both are 4-player partnership trick-taking games. In Meitra, the 'Blow' phase is like Bridge's auction, 'fields' are tricks, and 'pairs' refer to the number of tricks you aim to win.
overview.description: Meitra is a strategic 4-player, 2-team card game. It features an advanced gameplay combining the Blow (declaration) system, special Jack mechanics, and a detailed scoring system.
overview.objectiveDesc: Achieve the declared number of pairs in the Blow phase and be the first team to reach 10 points to win
overview.objectiveExample: Team Play: 2 players sitting opposite each other form a team; target score can be adjusted in settings

cards.title: Cards and Deck
cards.compositionDesc: Play with: 5-A + JOKER (53 cards total). 2, 3, 4 are excluded
cards.scoreCardsDesc: Use 2, 3, 4 cards separately for score display
cards.strengthExample: Value: JOKER, A, K, Q, J, 10, 9, 8, 7, 6, 5...

blow.title: Blow (Declaration) System
blow.description: In the Blow phase, you declare 'how many pairs out of 10 fields you can take' and 'which suit to use as trump'. This is the core of the game. A pair means the number of fields (tricks) you can win. Similar to Bridge's bidding phase, players compete to make the highest declaration.
blow.basicRuleDesc: Minimum 6 pairs required. Declare a combination of number of pairs and suit type (like Bridge's contract bidding)
blow.hierarchyNote: With the same number of pairs, stronger trump declarations take precedence (similar to Bridge's suit ranking)
blow.higherDeclarationDesc: ① Increase number of pairs ② Use stronger suit with same pairs
blow.higherDeclarationExample: Club 7 → Heart 7 (same pairs, stronger suit) / Club 8 (more pairs)
blow.practiceDesc: Experience the actual Blow declaration system and understand the higher declaration rules.

jack.title: JOKER and Jack Special System
jack.description: JOKER is always the strongest card. Also, Jacks (J) have special roles, and after the trump suit is determined, certain Jacks gain special strength.
jack.jokerDesc: Always the strongest card in any situation (strength 150)
jack.subJackDesc: Jack of the same color as trump suit (strength 18)
jack.traExceptionDesc: The Main J/Sub J system does not apply to Tra declarations. All Jacks are treated with normal strength.

play.title: Play Phase
play.description: After Blow declarations, play cards to compete for fields (tricks). Like Bridge, this is a trick-taking phase where you try to win the number of tricks you declared. The competition is about how many pairs (tricks) you can take out of 10 fields.
play.orderDesc: Play cards clockwise from the dealer (highest declarer), similar to Bridge's play phase
play.winnerDesc: Based on the card strength system, the player who played the strongest card wins the trick
play.baseSuitDesc: The suit of the first card played becomes the base suit for that field (like Bridge's lead suit)
play.baseSuitExample: ♠5 played first → ♠ is base suit → ♠ cards get +50 bonus
play.strengthDesc: Base strength + Trump bonus (+100) + Base suit bonus (+50)

broken.title: Broken & Negri System
broken.description: Under certain hand conditions, you enter a 'Broken' state with special rules. Also, selecting the weakest card (Negri) is an important element.
broken.judgmentDesc: Broken state when you have no face cards (A,K,Q,J) or only one Q
broken.requiredDesc: Must declare Broken if you have all four Jacks
broken.negriDesc: Each player selects the card they consider least useful in their hand

scoring.title: Scoring System
scoring.description: Score is calculated based on declared pairs and actual fields won.
scoring.calculatorDesc: Enter declared pairs and fields won to calculate actual score.
scoring.formulaDesc: Let X = declared pairs, Y = fields won
scoring.formulaExample: If Y≥X: 0.5×(Y-X)+X-5 points / If Y<X: Y-X points
scoring.tip1: Safe declarations (6-7 pairs) have lower failure risk
scoring.tip2: Bonus for exceeding declaration is modest (0.5×)
scoring.tip3: Penalty for failed declaration is severe (full difference)
scoring.tip4: High declarations have higher base points but greater risk

chombo.title: Chombo (Violation) System
chombo.description: Illegal actions or rule violations during the game are called Chombo, and penalties are imposed when pointed out by the opposing team.
chombo.negriForgetDesc: Violation when forgetting to select Negri card
chombo.negriForgetExample: Negri not selected at play start → Can be reported as violation
chombo.fourJackDesc: Violation when failing to declare mandatory Broken with 4 Jacks
chombo.lastTanzenDesc: Special violation when last card is JOKER
chombo.lastTanzenExample: Last card in hand is JOKER → Processed as special violation
chombo.wrongBrokenDesc: When declaring Broken without meeting Broken conditions
chombo.wrongBrokenExample: Declaring Broken with face cards → Can be reported as violation
chombo.reportSystemDesc: Only opposing team can point out violations, not within same team
chombo.reportSystemExample: Violation detected → Opposing team reports → Penalty applied

strategy.title: Strategy and Tips
strategy.blowTip1: Assess hand strength to predict how many pairs out of 10 fields you can take
strategy.blowTip2: Strong trumps are easier to declare but carry higher risk
strategy.blowTip3: Start with safe declarations around 6-7 pairs
strategy.blowTip4: Observe partner's declaration patterns for coordination
strategy.blowTip5: With 4 Jacks, mandatory Broken - declare honestly without hiding
strategy.playTip1: Trump cards are powerful but timing is crucial
strategy.playTip2: Be aware of base suit when playing cards
strategy.playTip3: Main/Sub Jacks are top-tier - decide whether to save or use early
strategy.playTip4: Play to leverage partner's strong cards
strategy.playTip5: Remember opponents' declarations and adjust fields to let them take
strategy.teamTip1: Support partner's declaration with your plays
strategy.teamTip2: Strategies to hinder opposing team's declarations are also important
strategy.teamTip3: Don't miss Chombo violations - point them out
strategy.teamTip4: Share score calculations to understand game situation
strategy.teamTip5: Take long-term view to reach 10 points
